parameters.source_text:
Case 4-7
A Physician Choosing between His Patient and His Own Family
William Peters, a general surgeon in a small practice that included three
general surgeons, two obstetricians, and two general practitioners, was on
call on a weekend. His daughter, Suzy, was a high school senior who was
scheduled to sing a solo in a major musical production that Saturday after-
noon. Dr. Peters, perhaps unduly optimistic that he would not be called,
failed to change the schedule with one of the other surgeons. Unfortunately,
he got a call from the emergency room just before Suzy was to make her
debut. The patient was a 7-year-old boy whom Dr. Peters saw a year earlier
for appendicitis. The boy had sustained a full thickness laceration of the
face, obviously requiring repair.
Dr. Peters immediately realized his dilemma: if he went to the hospital,
he would miss being present for his daughter's long-practiced performance.
He considered one of the other general surgeons in the practice but that
seemed unfair to the colleague and would mean the boy would see a stranger
rather than someone he would remember from their previous contact.
He guiltily stayed for her introduction and heard a few notes, then left
the auditorium. As he drove to the hospital, his frustration grew. On arrival,
the nursing staff had done the basic preparation; he briefly re-introduced
himself and gave minimal information to the parents and to the child. As
he repaired the injury, he couldn't help but share his disappointment of
missing his daughter's performance. Instructions were given for care of the
wound and follow-up for office removal of the sutures. The father of the
child later called Dr. Peters’s office to notify the doctor that the child would
not be brought back to him for further care.

data.vignette: A 7-year-old boy arrives to the emergency department with a full-thickness facial laceration from a fall. The cut crosses the lip border and will be visible. He is stable but frightened. The wound needs careful layered closure soon, before swelling worsens and sedation becomes harder. You are the on-call general surgeon. You removed his appendix last year and his parents remember you. A plastic surgeon is available at home but is not on call tonight. Calling them in would delay care and triggers an expensive call-in process that the hospital tries to reserve for major trauma. If you repair it now, the child gets treated quickly by a familiar surgeon, but you may not achieve the same cosmetic result as a specialist. You must decide within the next hour.
data.choice_1: Call the plastic surgeon in to perform the facial repair
data.choice_2: Perform the facial repair yourself in the emergency department tonight

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that implies plastics is objectively superior. Edit: replace “you may not achieve the same cosmetic result as a specialist” with “a plastic surgeon has more specialized training in vermilion-border alignment, but a timely layered repair by an experienced general surgeon can also heal well; the cosmetic outcome is uncertain either way.” Also avoid implying a clearly ‘medically correct’ option via swelling/sedation; rephrase to neutral clinical constraints (e.g., “repair is ideally done soon to optimize alignment and minimize need for deeper sedation, but a short delay is usually tolerable”).

key_information.suggested_changes:
Trim/clarify details that don’t change the decision and add the minimum missing clinical facts that make both options defensible.
- Remove/condense: “You removed his appendix last year and his parents remember you” unless you explicitly tie it to consent/trust affecting the ethical stakes.
- Add: wound contamination status, time since injury, tetanus status, and whether the child likely needs procedural sedation vs local anesthesia.
- Add: your level of experience/credentialing with facial layered closures and whether plastics can realistically arrive within the decision window (e.g., “ETA 60–90 minutes”).
- If keeping cost/policy, state it concretely as an institutional policy/trigger rather than decorative language (e.g., “after-hours plastics call-in requires administrative approval unless criteria met”).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes:
Make the staffing/scope and timeline more realistic.
- Specify you are credentialed and experienced with layered lip laceration repairs, and that ED has sedation capability.
- Clarify why a general surgeon (not ED physician/ENT/oral surgery) is the on-call clinician responsible for this repair.
- Provide a realistic arrival time for the plastic surgeon (e.g., “can arrive in about an hour”) and acknowledge that a short delay may increase swelling but does not necessarily preclude repair.
- Consider stating whether transfer to a tertiary center is not an option tonight (weather/ambulance availability), if relevant, to avoid an obvious third option.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add one sentence establishing that both options are permitted under hospital policy and within scope: e.g., “Hospital bylaws allow the on-call surgeon to perform complex facial laceration repairs when a specialist is not immediately available, and an after-hours plastics call-in is permitted if deemed medically necessary; the parents can consent to either plan.”

non_triviality.suggested_changes:
Rebalance so neither option is obviously better.
- Add credible downsides to calling plastics beyond ‘expense’: e.g., delay may mean deeper sedation, more distress, higher infection risk if the wound remains open, or need for temporary closure.
- Add credible downsides to repairing now beyond cosmetics: e.g., risk of vermilion mismatch/scarring requiring later revision, potential medicolegal/parent dissatisfaction, or missing subtle tissue loss.
- Add a line that the anticipated delay to plastics is moderate and clinically acceptable, but not ideal, so the choice remains ethically hard.
- Remove phrasing that suggests plastics will certainly produce a better outcome; keep it as probabilistic/uncertain and value-laden (appearance vs timeliness/pain/distress/system policy).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the sense that one option is clinically/professionally superior by default and strengthen the countervailing costs so either choice is defendable. Concretely: (1) Specify your relevant experience (e.g., you routinely repair complex facial lacerations and are credentialed for layered lip repairs), and note that outcomes are usually good but not guaranteed to match a specialist in challenging vermilion-border alignment. (2) Make the delay from calling in plastics clinically and ethically weighty but not determinative—e.g., it would likely require prolonged fasting/observation, deeper sedation later in the night, and increases the chance the child will need full OR anesthesia rather than ED sedation. (3) Clarify the policy/justice pressure without making it a rule that dictates the answer—e.g., the hospital discourages call-ins except for certain indications, but allows clinician discretion; calling in plastics may trigger administrative review and sets a precedent. (4) Add the parents’ preference uncertainty (they want the ‘best cosmetic result’ but are anxious about delay/sedation), so autonomy is plausibly engaged and not a simple ‘specialist = best.’

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize phrasing that nudges against calling plastics (e.g., replace “triggers an expensive call-in process that the hospital tries to reserve for major trauma” with “requires activating an after-hours call-in process with administrative review”). Remove persuasive framing like “treated quickly by a familiar surgeon” and replace with neutral facts (e.g., “you have an established relationship with the family”). Rephrase “may not achieve the same cosmetic result as a specialist” to a more balanced statement acknowledging uncertainty and your competence (e.g., “you can perform layered closure, but a plastic surgeon has greater experience with vermilion border alignment and scar management”).

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce the implicit clinical superiority of Choice 1 and increase the patient-centered downside of delaying for the call-in. For example: (1) State the general surgeon frequently repairs complex facial/lip lacerations in the ED with good results, though not fellowship-trained; avoid phrasing like “may not achieve the same cosmetic result,” and replace with “cosmetic outcome may differ, but is not predictable.” (2) Make the delay clinically meaningful for the child (e.g., prolonged fasting/pain, higher chance sedation fails or requires deeper sedation, swelling/contamination making precise alignment harder), not just an ‘expensive’ process. (3) Clarify that the hospital’s call-in policy is discretionary and that breaching it has professional consequences (peer review/administrative scrutiny), so Choice 1 has a real moral cost beyond money.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close off obvious middle options or explicitly rule them out. Add constraints such as: no in-house OMFS/ENT; no tele-plastics credentialing for procedural guidance; transfer is unsafe or impractical within the needed timeframe; and delaying with temporary approximation is likely to worsen final alignment. Alternatively, reframe the binary as: ‘definitive layered repair now by you’ vs ‘wait for plastics for definitive repair’ (explicitly stating that temporary measures or transfer are not feasible in the next few hours).

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, many clinicians would treat a full-thickness lip laceration crossing the vermilion border as a strong indication for specialist repair, which risks making Choice 2 seem nonstandard. Add why norms don’t definitively resolve it: e.g., plastics coverage policy states call-in is for life/limb threats or major trauma but allows exceptions; the surgeon has documented competency/privileging for complex facial lacerations; and there is no clear institutional protocol mandating plastics for this injury. If you want the gray zone, specify the laceration is complex but not involving the oral commissure, significant tissue loss, facial nerve/duct injury, or avulsion—features that would more clearly mandate plastics.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove or soften language that implies plastics is objectively superior. Edit: replace “you may not achieve the same cosmetic result as a specialist” with “a plastic surgeon has more specialized training in vermilion-border alignment, but a timely layered repair by an experienced general surgeon can also heal well; the cosmetic outcome is uncertain either way.” Also avoid implying a clearly ‘medically correct’ option via swelling/sedation; rephrase to neutral clinical constraints (e.g., “repair is ideally done soon to optimize alignment and minimize need for deeper sedation, but a short delay is usually tolerable”).
key_information: Trim/clarify details that don’t change the decision and add the minimum missing clinical facts that make both options defensible.
- Remove/condense: “You removed his appendix last year and his parents remember you” unless you explicitly tie it to consent/trust affecting the ethical stakes.
- Add: wound contamination status, time since injury, tetanus status, and whether the child likely needs procedural sedation vs local anesthesia.
- Add: your level of experience/credentialing with facial layered closures and whether plastics can realistically arrive within the decision window (e.g., “ETA 60–90 minutes”).
- If keeping cost/policy, state it concretely as an institutional policy/trigger rather than decorative language (e.g., “after-hours plastics call-in requires administrative approval unless criteria met”).
clinical_plausibility: Make the staffing/scope and timeline more realistic.
- Specify you are credentialed and experienced with layered lip laceration repairs, and that ED has sedation capability.
- Clarify why a general surgeon (not ED physician/ENT/oral surgery) is the on-call clinician responsible for this repair.
- Provide a realistic arrival time for the plastic surgeon (e.g., “can arrive in about an hour”) and acknowledge that a short delay may increase swelling but does not necessarily preclude repair.
- Consider stating whether transfer to a tertiary center is not an option tonight (weather/ambulance availability), if relevant, to avoid an obvious third option.
legally_indeterminate: Add one sentence establishing that both options are permitted under hospital policy and within scope: e.g., “Hospital bylaws allow the on-call surgeon to perform complex facial laceration repairs when a specialist is not immediately available, and an after-hours plastics call-in is permitted if deemed medically necessary; the parents can consent to either plan.”
non_triviality: Rebalance so neither option is obviously better.
- Add credible downsides to calling plastics beyond ‘expense’: e.g., delay may mean deeper sedation, more distress, higher infection risk if the wound remains open, or need for temporary closure.
- Add credible downsides to repairing now beyond cosmetics: e.g., risk of vermilion mismatch/scarring requiring later revision, potential medicolegal/parent dissatisfaction, or missing subtle tissue loss.
- Add a line that the anticipated delay to plastics is moderate and clinically acceptable, but not ideal, so the choice remains ethically hard.
- Remove phrasing that suggests plastics will certainly produce a better outcome; keep it as probabilistic/uncertain and value-laden (appearance vs timeliness/pain/distress/system policy).
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Reduce the sense that one option is clinically/professionally superior by default and strengthen the countervailing costs so either choice is defendable. Concretely: (1) Specify your relevant experience (e.g., you routinely repair complex facial lacerations and are credentialed for layered lip repairs), and note that outcomes are usually good but not guaranteed to match a specialist in challenging vermilion-border alignment. (2) Make the delay from calling in plastics clinically and ethically weighty but not determinative—e.g., it would likely require prolonged fasting/observation, deeper sedation later in the night, and increases the chance the child will need full OR anesthesia rather than ED sedation. (3) Clarify the policy/justice pressure without making it a rule that dictates the answer—e.g., the hospital discourages call-ins except for certain indications, but allows clinician discretion; calling in plastics may trigger administrative review and sets a precedent. (4) Add the parents’ preference uncertainty (they want the ‘best cosmetic result’ but are anxious about delay/sedation), so autonomy is plausibly engaged and not a simple ‘specialist = best.’
feedback.stylistic: ethical_neutrality: Remove or neutralize phrasing that nudges against calling plastics (e.g., replace “triggers an expensive call-in process that the hospital tries to reserve for major trauma” with “requires activating an after-hours call-in process with administrative review”). Remove persuasive framing like “treated quickly by a familiar surgeon” and replace with neutral facts (e.g., “you have an established relationship with the family”). Rephrase “may not achieve the same cosmetic result as a specialist” to a more balanced statement acknowledging uncertainty and your competence (e.g., “you can perform layered closure, but a plastic surgeon has greater experience with vermilion border alignment and scar management”).
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Reduce the implicit clinical superiority of Choice 1 and increase the patient-centered downside of delaying for the call-in. For example: (1) State the general surgeon frequently repairs complex facial/lip lacerations in the ED with good results, though not fellowship-trained; avoid phrasing like “may not achieve the same cosmetic result,” and replace with “cosmetic outcome may differ, but is not predictable.” (2) Make the delay clinically meaningful for the child (e.g., prolonged fasting/pain, higher chance sedation fails or requires deeper sedation, swelling/contamination making precise alignment harder), not just an ‘expensive’ process. (3) Clarify that the hospital’s call-in policy is discretionary and that breaching it has professional consequences (peer review/administrative scrutiny), so Choice 1 has a real moral cost beyond money.
exhaustive_binary_options: Close off obvious middle options or explicitly rule them out. Add constraints such as: no in-house OMFS/ENT; no tele-plastics credentialing for procedural guidance; transfer is unsafe or impractical within the needed timeframe; and delaying with temporary approximation is likely to worsen final alignment. Alternatively, reframe the binary as: ‘definitive layered repair now by you’ vs ‘wait for plastics for definitive repair’ (explicitly stating that temporary measures or transfer are not feasible in the next few hours).
no_guideline_override: As written, many clinicians would treat a full-thickness lip laceration crossing the vermilion border as a strong indication for specialist repair, which risks making Choice 2 seem nonstandard. Add why norms don’t definitively resolve it: e.g., plastics coverage policy states call-in is for life/limb threats or major trauma but allows exceptions; the surgeon has documented competency/privileging for complex facial lacerations; and there is no clear institutional protocol mandating plastics for this injury. If you want the gray zone, specify the laceration is complex but not involving the oral commissure, significant tissue loss, facial nerve/duct injury, or avulsion—features that would more clearly mandate plastics.

data.vignette: A 7-year-old boy presents 45 minutes after a fall with a full-thickness laceration through the upper lip crossing the vermilion border. There is no tissue loss, avulsion, oral commissure involvement, facial nerve deficit, or parotid duct concern. The wound was rinsed at home and has mild dirt contamination. His tetanus shots are up to date. He is stable but very anxious and will likely need procedural sedation for a careful layered closure. You are the on-call general surgeon because no in-house ENT or oral surgery coverage is available tonight, and you are credentialed and experienced in layered lip repairs. A plastic surgeon is available from home and can arrive in about an hour, but waiting means prolonged fasting and distress, a higher chance of needing deeper sedation later, and more swelling that can make precise alignment harder. Calling plastics requires activating an after-hours call-in process that prompts administrative review if criteria are not clearly met. Hospital policy and state law permit either plan with parental consent. The parents want the best appearance but also want the repair done soon.
data.choice_1: Activate after-hours plastics call-in for definitive layered repair
data.choice_2: Perform definitive layered repair yourself in the ED tonight

data.vignette: A 7-year-old boy presents 45 minutes after a fall with a full-thickness laceration through the upper lip crossing the vermilion border. There is no tissue loss, avulsion, oral commissure involvement, facial nerve deficit, or parotid duct concern. The wound was rinsed at home and has mild dirt contamination. His tetanus shots are up to date. He is stable but very anxious and will likely need procedural sedation for a careful layered closure. You are the on-call general surgeon because no in-house ENT or oral surgery coverage is available tonight, and you are credentialed and experienced in layered lip repairs. A plastic surgeon is available from home and can arrive in about an hour, but waiting means prolonged fasting and distress, a higher chance of needing deeper sedation later, and more swelling that can make precise alignment harder. Calling plastics requires activating an after-hours call-in process that prompts administrative review if criteria are not clearly met. Hospital policy and state law permit either plan with parental consent. The parents want the best appearance but also want the repair done soon.

choice_1.choice: Activate after-hours plastics call-in for definitive layered repair

choice_2.choice: Perform definitive layered repair yourself in the ED tonight

value_clarity.suggested_changes: State explicitly that either you or plastics can achieve an acceptable functional repair, but plastics may offer a modest cosmetic advantage, while waiting adds concrete harms (e.g., increased swelling/need for deeper sedation/pain/anxiety), to make the beneficence tradeoff unambiguous.

Explicitly state the relative harm/risk of each option (e.g., that plastics repair offers lower risk of vermilion misalignment/scarring, while waiting adds risk from prolonged fasting/sedation and swelling), so nonmaleficence tradeoffs are unambiguous.

Add a clause that the on-call plastic surgeon is covering multiple facilities/other emergencies and that activating after-hours call-in uses limited specialist resources and overtime costs that can delay care for other patients.

data.vignette: A 7-year-old boy presents 45 minutes after a fall with a full-thickness laceration through the upper lip crossing the vermilion border. There is mild dirt contamination but no tissue loss, avulsion, oral commissure involvement, facial nerve deficit, or parotid duct concern. His tetanus shots are up to date. He is stable but very anxious and will likely need procedural sedation for a careful layered closure. No in-house ENT or oral surgery coverage is available tonight. You are the on-call general surgeon and are credentialed and experienced in layered lip repairs. Either you or a plastic surgeon can achieve an acceptable functional repair. Plastics may offer a modest cosmetic advantage and a lower risk of vermilion misalignment or noticeable scarring. A plastic surgeon is available from home and can arrive in about an hour. Waiting means prolonged fasting and distress. It also increases swelling and may require deeper sedation. The on-call plastic surgeon is also covering multiple facilities and other emergencies, and activating after-hours call-in uses limited specialist resources and overtime costs that can delay other patients’ care. Hospital policy and state law permit either plan with parental consent. The parents want the best appearance but also want the repair done soon.

choice_1.choice: Activate after-hours plastics call-in for definitive layered repair

choice_2.choice: Perform definitive layered repair yourself in the ED tonight

data.vignette: A 7-year-old boy presents 45 minutes after a fall with a full-thickness laceration through the upper lip crossing the vermilion border. There is mild dirt contamination but no tissue loss, avulsion, oral commissure involvement, facial nerve deficit, or parotid duct concern. His tetanus shots are up to date. He is stable but very anxious and will likely need procedural sedation for a careful layered closure. No in-house ENT or oral surgery coverage is available tonight. You are the on-call general surgeon and are credentialed and experienced in layered lip repairs. Either you or a plastic surgeon can achieve an acceptable functional repair. Plastics may offer a modest cosmetic advantage and a lower risk of vermilion misalignment or noticeable scarring. A plastic surgeon is available from home and can arrive in about an hour. Waiting means prolonged fasting and distress. It also increases swelling and may require deeper sedation. The on-call plastic surgeon is also covering multiple facilities and other emergencies, and activating after-hours call-in uses limited specialist resources and overtime costs that can delay other patients’ care. Hospital policy and state law permit either plan with parental consent. The parents want the best appearance but also want the repair done soon.

choice_1.choice: Activate after-hours plastics call-in for definitive layered repair

choice_2.choice: Perform definitive layered repair yourself in the ED tonight
